questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

 

The test used for the detection of ketone bodies (KB) in the given scenario of a 15-year-old boy with type I diabetes mellitus is Rothera's Test.

 

Rothera's Test involves the reaction of acetoacetate with sodium nitroprusside and glycine in an alkaline medium. This reaction forms a purple-colored complex, indicating the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of reducing sugars, such as glucose, in a solution.

 

Option C. Seliwanoff's test is used to differentiate between different types of sugars, particularly distinguishing ketoses from aldoses.

 

Option D. Biuret test The Biuret test is used to detect the presence of proteins in a sample by reacting with peptide bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.

 

In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bag & Mask ventilation 

 

  • In a neonate presenting with a scaphoid abdomen, certain respiratory interventions need to be carefully considered due to the high risk of underlying conditions like congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). 

 

This is contraindicated in neonates with a scaphoid abdomen suspected of having CDH. The use of positive pressure from bag and mask ventilation can exacerbate the displacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through the diaphragmatic defect, potentially worsening respiratory distress and leading to further compromise of pulmonary function. This method of ventilation can increase the risk of pneumothorax, gastric distention, and further reduce lung volume, which is already compromised in CDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation): Like intubation, IPPV is used via a mechanical ventilator after intubation and can provide controlled and safe respiratory support. It is also appropriate in these scenarios to ensure that airway pressure is managed carefully to avoid exacerbating the hernia.

 

Option C. Intubation: This is the preferred method for securing the airway in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen when CDH is suspected. Intubation allows for controlled ventilation settings, minimizes gastric distension, and helps manage the baby’s respiratory status more effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The critical point in managing a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen, particularly when a condition like CDH is suspected, involves avoiding exacerbation of the hernia through inappropriate respiratory support techniques. Opting for intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation instead of bag & mask ventilation is crucial to prevent further complications and stabilize the infant's condition. Properly securing the airway and ensuring adequate ventilation without increasing the risk of further pulmonary or gastrointestinal injury is essential in the initial management of these patients.

questions.text: In Which of the following pathways, cyclooxygenase is involved? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostaglandin

 

Prostaglandins are derived from arachidonic acid, which is an essential fatty acid found in cell membranes. This process is mediated by Cyclooxygenases called, COX-1 and COX-2

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Kreb's cycle: Kreb's cycle is the terminal pathway for the oxidative catabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and fatty acids.

 

Option C. Leukotrienes: Leukotrienes are also produced from arachidonic acid with the help of lipoxygenases.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is essential for the carboxylation of glutamate residues in certain proteins required for blood clotting. This process does not involve cyclooxygenase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclooxygenase is involved in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway, converting arachidonic acid into prostaglandins, which are key mediators of inflammation, pain, and other physiological responses.

questions.text: How is cerebral perfusion pressure calculated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure


Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated as mean arterial pressure (MAP) - intracranial pressure (ICP).

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the net pressure gradient that drives oxygen delivery to cerebral tissue. It is the difference between the mean arterial pressure (MAP) and the intracranial pressure (ICP), measured in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg). If ICP values are not readily available, central venous pressure (CVP) may be used.

 

Normal CPP lies between 60- and 80-mm Hg,

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated by subtracting the intracranial pressure (ICP) from the mean arterial pressure (MAP). This measurement is crucial for ensuring adequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain.

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, presents with blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also experienced similar issues and unfortunately passed away at the age of 2 weeks. What is the probable diagnosis?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • The male baby's current condition, characterized by blisters appearing in areas of friction, along with a similar history in a sibling, strongly suggests a diagnosis of a genetic condition called as epidermolysis bullosa congenita.
  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechano-bullous disease where blisters develop in response to mechanical trauma, often occurring in regions prone to friction such as the hands, feet, elbows, and knees.

 

 

Various types of Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) & Defects associated with them:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis in a neonate presenting with blistering at areas of friction, especially with a similar family history and early demise in a sibling, is Epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic condition causing extremely fragile skin leading to blister formation with minimal trauma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16

questions.text: In the accompanying illustration, a treatment approach for a patient with lymphatic filariasis is depicted. Which type of preventive method is illustrated in this scenario? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disability limitation

 

  • The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection.
  • Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

 

Option C. Primary prevention: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Health promotion: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disability limitation is a mode of tertiary prevention aimed at managing existing disease and preventing further complications, as illustrated in the treatment approach for a patient with chronic lymphatic filariasis in the image.

questions.text: Insulin independent absorption occurs in all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adipose

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, primarily using GLUT4 transporters activated by insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC: Red Blood Cells utilize GLUT1 transporters for glucose absorption, which is insulin-independent and crucial for their energy needs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: While the pancreas plays a role in insulin production, its glucose absorption is not predominantly insulin-independent.

 

Option D. Brain: The brain absorbs glucose independently of insulin, using GLUT3 transporters, essential for its constant energy requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, while RBCs, pancreas, and brain utilize insulin-independent mechanisms for glucose absorption.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding KF ring? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement

2. Is pathognomonic for Wilson's disease

3. Resolves with desferrioxamine

4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement

5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 5 only.

 

Statement 1: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is frequently seen in patients with neurological involvement due to Wilson’s disease, but it may not be present in all cases.

 

Statement 5: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is a copper deposit seen at the superior and inferior poles of the corneal Descemet's membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: While the KF ring is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, it is not solely pathognomonic because it can appear in other chronic cholestatic liver conditions.

 

Statement 3: Desferrioxamine is used for iron chelation and is not effective for copper removal in Wilson's disease. Treatment for copper overload involves agents like penicillamine or trientine.

 

Statement 4: Not all patients with hepatic involvement due to Wilson's disease will have visible KF rings, as their presence correlates more strongly with the duration and severity of copper accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

KF can be seen in disorders causing chronic cholestasis. Seen in ~99% of patients with neuro wilson's, 44-60% with hepatic involvement.

 

Desferioxamine is chelating agent in iron toxicity. 

 

Reference - Harrison/Liver/Wilsons/Chap 344

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma
  2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination
  3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection
  4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Statements 1, 3 and 4 are true.

 

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma: This is true. Mammography is an essential tool in the early detection of breast cancer, but it has been associated with over-diagnosis. As a result, some women might receive unnecessary treatment for non-life-threatening tumors.

 

2. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection: This is true. Visual inspection of the oral cavity can detect precancerous lesions or early signs of oral cancer. Regular dental check-ups often include a visual check for signs of oral cancer.

 

3. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear: This is true. A Pap smear (or Pap test) is a procedure to test for cervical cancer in women. The test involves collecting cells from the cervix to be examined under a microscope to detect abnormalities that can turn into cervical cancer.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination: This statement is not entirely accurate. While a digital rectal examination (DRE) can detect some abnormalities or tumors in the rectum, it is not the primary method for colon cancer screening. The primary methods for colon cancer screening include fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, and colonoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates.
  2. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy.
  3. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  4. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  5. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

choices.text: Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS
IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment
Areflexia in the weaker arm is included in diagnostic criteria

questions.text: Regarding Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) in children, which of the following statements is false? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS

 

Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange, PEX) is a well-established and effective treatment in GBS, including in refractory or severe cases. It is considered equivalent in efficacy to IVIG and may be used in patients not responding to IVIG (controversial, and sequential administration of PEX after IVIG is not recommended, but some clinicians try on a case-by-case basis), or if IVIG is contraindicated or unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment: Correct. IVIG can be used as first-line treatment, having equal efficacy to plasma exchange in GBS management.

 

Option C. Areflexia in the weaker arm is included in diagnostic criteria: Correct. Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criterion according to Brighton criteria. GBS is a demyelinating disease affecting large fibers that form the basis of reflex arcs.

 

Option D. Albumino-cytological dissociation: Correct. It is a classic feature of GBS, with high protein in CSF but normal cell count (<10 cells). Any cell count >50 essentially rules out GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmapheresis and IVIG are effective treatment options for GBS, including refractory cases, with neither being superior to the other. Never use immunosuppression or steroids in acute GBS.

 

 

Level of diagnostic certainty in Brighton criteria for GBS

choices.text: Inhibition of calcineurin
AMP kinase stimulation
IMP dehydrogenase inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin
 

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant drug that acts by inhibiting Calcineurin.
  • Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase required for the induction of T cell lymphokine production and proliferation.
  • Cyclosporine inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells, to form a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex. This drug-receptor complex specifically and competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin.
  • This, in turn, inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for interleukin (IL)-2 and other factors.
  • Ultimately, the proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced, resulting in immunomodulation.
  • Indications: It is the most effective drug for the prevention of Graft rejection reaction. It is also used as a second line drug in autoimmune disease like severe Rheumatoid arthritis, uveitis, inflammatory bowel disease and dermatomyositis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AMP kinase is stimulated by metformin used in treating T2DM
 

Option C. IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by mycophenolate mofetil, also used in the prophylaxis of transplant rejection.

 

Option D. Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase is inhibited by leflunomide, a pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor indicated for the management of rheumatoid arthritis in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclosporine exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby preventing the activation of T cells and reducing the production of cytokines such as IL-2. This mechanism is crucial for its role in preventing graft rejection and managing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

 

Involves the contents of the orbit including fat and muscle, often secondary to sinus infections, particularly the ethmoid sinus.

 

Symptoms include painful eye movements, protrusion of the eyeball (proptosis), decreased vision, and fever.

 

This condition can be sight-threatening and requires urgent treatment.

 

  • For the 35-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis presenting with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever, the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is most consistent with the symptoms and the findings on the computed tomography (CT) scan. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preseptal Cellulitis with Sinusitis: Involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, typically without eye protrusion or vision changes.Fever and eyelid swelling are common, but the involvement of the eye as described suggests a deeper infection.

 

Option C. Subperiosteal Abscess: This is an accumulation of pus between the orbit and the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically a complication of orbital cellulitis. It may lead to eye protrusion and restricted eye movements, but it's typically identified on imaging as a distinct abscess rather than generalized infection signs.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: A broad term that can refer to any soft tissue infection but without specifying involvement of the orbital area in relation to the sinuses would be less specific compared to orbital cellulitis with sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

questions.text: Match the diseases with their maximum incubation period. [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b

 

The incubation periods for the diseases listed are as follows:

 

  • Hepatitis A: Maximum incubation period is 50 days.
  • Chickenpox: Maximum incubation period is 21 days.
  • SARS: Maximum incubation period is 10 days.
  • Syphilis: Maximum incubation period is 90 days.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, is a common viral illness caused primarily by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The disease typically affects young children. It is characterized by a high fever lasting for three to five days, which abruptly resolves and is followed by the appearance of a rash. The rash consists of small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. It is typically nonpruritic, blanching, and can persist from one to two days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

In contrast, petechial rashes are small, pinpoint, red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin and are associated with the following diseases:

 

Option A. Zika Virus: Zika virus infection can cause a mild, dengue-like illness, which includes symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. The rash can be maculopapular, and in some cases, petechiae can be observed.

 

 

Option C. Kyasanur Forest Disease: This is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to South India. It is caused by the Kyasanur Forest disease virus (KFDV) and presents with high fever, headache, severe muscle pain, vomiting, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hemorrhagic manifestations, including petechiae.

 

 

Option D. West Nile Fever: This disease is caused by the West Nile virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, including fever, headache, body aches, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes, and in severe cases, neurological complications. Petechial rashes can occur in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Eonism can be defined as? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wearing clothes of opposite sex

 

  • Eonism /Transvestism involves wearing clothes of the opposite sex to derive pleasure.
  • Eonism is named for Charles Eon de Beaumont, a French political adventurer who died in 1810 after posing as a woman for many years.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Public display of genitalia – Exhibitionism, where an individual derives pleasure from exposing their genitals to others in public.

 

Option C. Seeing a male undressing: This can be a form of voyeurism, though it is not specifically defined as such. Voyeurism typically involves deriving pleasure from secretly observing others who are undressing or engaging in sexual activities.

 

Option D. Seeing a female undressing- Voyeurism, where an individual derives pleasure from observing females undressing.

 

Educational Objective

 

Eonism or transvestism is the act of wearing clothes of the opposite sex for pleasure, named after Charles Eon de Beaumont.

questions.text: All of the following cause a right shift of the oxygen- hemoglobin dissociation curve, except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased HbF

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve describes the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) and the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin in the blood. A left shift of the curve indicates an increase in the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, resulting in more oxygen being bound to hemoglobin at a given PO2.

 

Increased HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin (HbA), which causes a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve. This allows fetal hemoglobin to extract oxygen more efficiently from the mother's blood in the placenta, where the PO2 is lower than in the adult circulation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Factors causing a right shift (decreased affinity for oxygen):

 

Option B. Raised 2,3 BPG: Increased levels of 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate decrease hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

 

Option C. Acidosis: A decrease in blood pH (increased H⁺ concentration) reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

 

Option D. Increased CO₂: Higher levels of carbon dioxide also decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right with factors that decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, such as increased 2,3 BPG, acidosis, and increased CO₂. In contrast, increased fetal hemoglobin (HbF) causes a left shift, indicating higher oxygen affinity.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the Green marked structure in the image in anatomical position? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coccyx

 

The marked structure in the image is the ischial spine. In anatomical position, the ischial spine is located at the level of the coccyx. This is important in various medical procedures, including the pudendal nerve block, commonly used in obstetrics and gynecology. The ischial spine serves as a significant landmark for these procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: Incorrect. The L4 vertebra is located much higher in the vertebral column, around the lower back region, and is not associated with the ischial spine.

 

Option B. L4-L5: Incorrect. This option refers to the intervertebral disc space between L4 and L5, which is also in the lower back but not related to the pelvic region or ischial spine.

 

Option C. S3-S5: Incorrect. Although the ischial spine can be aligned with these sacral vertebrae in certain positions like lithotomy (during childbirth), but here the question is about anatomical position so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial spine in anatomical position aligns with the coccyx, serving as an important landmark for various medical procedures.

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.

 

The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16

 

Fingerprints begin to form between 12 to 16 weeks of intrauterine life. By this stage, the basic patterns of the ridges on the skin are established. The formation continues, and fingerprints are complete by approximately 24 weeks of intrauterine life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fingerprints start developing between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life and are completed by 24 weeks, providing a unique identification for the individual that remains unchanged throughout their life.

questions.text: A patient had fever and sore throat for which he was started on antibiotic treatment. He develops abdominal pain. He has eosinophiluria and also has WBC casts in his urine. What is the likely diagnosis of the patient? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulointerstitial nephritis

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis, also known as acute allergic interstitial nephritis, is often caused by an allergic reaction to medications such as antibiotics. In this scenario, the patient had a fever and sore throat and was subsequently treated with antibiotics, likely from the penicillin group. Penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics are common culprits in causing type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, leading to the presence of eosinophils in the urine (eosinophiluria). This condition is also associated with the presence of WBC casts in the urine, indicating inflammation of the renal interstitium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This condition typically presents with RBC casts rather than WBC casts and does not involve eosinophiluria. It follows a streptococcal infection and involves immune complex deposition in the glomeruli.

 

Option C. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis is characterized by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to glomerulonephritis. It is not typically associated with eosinophiluria and primarily presents with RBC casts.

 

Option D. Rhabdomyolysis: Rhabdomyolysis involves the breakdown of muscle tissue, leading to the release of muscle contents into the bloodstream, including myoglobin, which can cause renal damage. It is characterized by elevated creatine kinase levels and does not present with eosinophiluria or WBC casts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis can present with eosinophiluria and WBC casts in the urine, often following antibiotic treatment, particularly with beta-lactam antibiotics. This condition results from an allergic reaction causing inflammation in the renal interstitium.

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tangier’s disease

 

Tangier's disease is an inherited disorder characterized by significantly reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood. This condition can lead to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and organs. Individuals with Tangier's disease may have enlarged orange tonsils and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease as shown in the picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman's Disease: Wolman's disease is a severe form of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) deficiency, a rare genetic disorder. It is characterized by the complete absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the buildup of fats in various tissues and organs. Symptoms typically appear in infancy and may include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), diarrhea/steatorrhea (fatty stools), and vomiting. This condition can be life-threatening.

 

Option B. Gaucher's Disease: Gaucher's disease is another genetic disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It results in the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucocerebroside in various organs and tissues, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Common symptoms include an enlarged spleen and liver, anemia, low platelet counts, and bone abnormalities. There are different types of Gaucher's disease, and the severity can vary.

 

Option D. Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system. It is caused by the absence or deficiency of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A, which leads to the buildup of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nerve cells. Symptoms typically appear in early childhood and include developmental regression, loss of motor skills, and a cherry-red spot in the eye. Tay-Sachs disease is progressive and ultimately fatal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia

 

ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).

 

  • So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Enlarged lymph nodes
    • Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals. It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with 15 days of fever and altered sensorium for 1 day. A rapid diagnostic test was done, and Plasmodium falciparum was diagnosed. Which of the following is not a complication? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial pH >7.2

 

An arterial pH >7.2, however, is not considered a complication of severe malaria. In fact, severe acidosis is defined by an arterial pH of less than 7.25, and it is a sign of severe malaria. Therefore, an arterial pH >7.2 does not indicate severe malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Plasmodium falciparum malaria is a severe form of malaria that can lead to numerous complications. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines several criteria for severe malaria, many of which are seen in complicated cases of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Option A. Blood glucose <40 mg/dL: Severe hypoglycemia is a known complication of severe malaria, particularly in patients treated with quinine.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine - 5.2: This indicates severe renal impairment. Serum creatinine levels above 3 mg/dL or reduced urine output despite rehydration are markers of severe malaria.

 

Option D. Unarousable coma: Cerebral malaria, which includes unarousable coma or seizures, is one of the most severe complications of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic criteria for identifying complicated falciparum malaria, based on clinical and laboratory findings:

 

  1. Arterial pH: An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria.
  2. Bicarbonate Levels: A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria.
  3. Base Deficit: A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease.
  4. Hemoglobin: A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity.
  5. Venous Lactate: A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection.
  6. Blood Glucose: A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria.
  7. Creatinine Levels: A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria.
  8. Urine Output: A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery: The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease comprised of four components:

 

  1. Right ventricular hypertrophy –Boot shaped heart
  2. Ventricular septal defect – no heart failure
  3. Overriding of aorta
  4. Pulmonary stenosis (infundibulum)-Oligemia

 

If ASD plus – pentalogy of Fallot

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebstein's anomaly: Typically presents with an enlarged and downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which is not specifically indicated by the features in this X-ray.

 

Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA): Generally shows a characteristic "egg on a string" sign on chest X-ray, which is not evident in this image.

 

Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC): Would show features like a "snowman" or "figure of 8" heart due to dilatation of the supra-cardiac veins, which is not visible here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a distinctive boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, correlating with the anatomical components of this congenital heart defect, making it a key diagnostic feature in cyanotic pediatric patients.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. Her vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. Which of the following is used as first-line management to treat the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The patient's ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia. This type of tachycardia, in a stable patient, is initially managed with vagal maneuvers such as carotid sinus massage or the Valsalva maneuver. These maneuvers aim to increase parasympathetic tone and slow conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node. If vagal maneuvers are ineffective or not feasible, the next step is to administer an AV nodal blocker.

 

Adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment for stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia. It works by transiently blocking the AV node, thereby interrupting the re-entrant circuit responsible for the tachycardia. The initial dose of adenosine is 6 mg administered rapidly IV push, followed by a 10 ml saline flush. If the tachycardia persists, additional doses of 12 mg may be given, with a maximum cumulative dose of 30 mg. Adenosine has a very short half-life of approximately 8 to 10 seconds, necessitating rapid (IV push) administration and immediate follow-up with normal saline to ensure efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is used for the treatment of various types of arrhythmias, including wide complex tachycardias (regular and monomorphic rhythm).

 

Option B. DC Cardioversion: Direct current (DC) cardioversion is used in cases of hemodynamic instability or when pharmacological treatment fails. It is not the first-line treatment for a stable patient presenting with regular narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can be used to manage atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm, because in that case adenosine is contraindicated).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia, adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24 hr urinary total metanephrines

 

The 24-hour urinary metanephrines test is considered the gold standard and first-line test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. The test should include fractionated catecholamines for comprehensive evaluation. This test is preferred due to its high sensitivity and specificity in detecting these rare neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MIBG scan: This is a nuclear medicine imaging test that can be useful for localizing pheochromocytoma and ruling out multifocal or metastatic disease, but it's not the initial diagnostic test. It's typically performed after biochemical confirmation of the disease.

 

Option C. Plasma catecholamines: While plasma catecholamines can be measured as part of the routine testing, they are not as reliable as urinary metanephrines due to their fluctuating levels and potential for false positives.

 

Option D. MRI of the whole abdomen: This is an imaging study used for tumor localization after biochemical confirmation of pheochromocytoma. It's not appropriate as an initial diagnostic test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 24-hour urinary metanephrines test with fractionated catecholamines is the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. Plasma metanephrines can be considered in high-risk populations (such as those with a family history or genetic syndromes).

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h
  2. Start injection ceftriaxone
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis
  4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

When managing a patient with fever and nuchal rigidity (suggesting possible meningitis), the correct order of steps is:

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h: Establishing IV access is the first priority to ensure hydration and create a route for medication administration.
  2. 4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture: The lumbar puncture should be performed early to collect CSF samples before antimicrobial therapy alters the CSF findings.
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis: Once the CSF is collected, it must be promptly sent for laboratory analysis to identify potential pathogens and guide targeted therapy.
  4. Start injection ceftriaxone: After CSF collection, empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone should be initiated. This ensures that treatment doesn't interfere with CSF culture results while still providing timely antimicrobial coverage.

 

This sequence prioritizes obtaining diagnostic samples before starting antimicrobial therapy, which is critical for accurate diagnosis while not unduly delaying treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

choices.text: Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith
Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.text: An elderly lady presents with abdominal pain and distension. She has a history of chronic constipation. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sigmoid volvulus

 

Explanation:

 

The abdominal X-ray shows a characteristic "coffee bean sign," which is indicative of a sigmoid volvulus. This radiological sign represents a massively distended sigmoid colon twisted on itself, resembling a bent tube or coffee bean. This condition is more common in elderly individuals, particularly those with a history of chronic constipation, due to the increased bowel length and mobility, combined with decreased bowel tone. Sigmoid volvulus can lead to severe abdominal pain and distension, as observed in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith: Typically presents with signs of obstruction but lacks the specific 'coffee bean' appearance associated with volvulus.

 

Option C. Cecal volvulus: Would show a single dilated loop of bowel, often with haustrations, and generally appears in a different location and shape compared to the sigmoid volvulus.

 

Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation: Would likely show signs of free air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, which is not visible in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Identify true statements about familial adenomatous polyposis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Autosomal recessive inheritance
  2. If not treated, all cases progress to adenocarcinoma colon.
  3. KRAS mutations cause familial adenomatous polyposis
  4. It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a hereditary condition characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum, often numbering in the hundreds to thousands. The condition is caused by mutations in the APC gene (chromosome 5q), leading to autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

True Statements:

 

Statement 2: If not treated, all cases of FAP will progress to colorectal adenocarcinoma. This is because the polyps have a high potential to become malignant if not removed or if the patient does not undergo a prophylactic colectomy.

 

Statement 4: FAP is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium, which is often used as a marker for the condition, especially in screening family members.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: FAP is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, not autosomal recessive. This means that a single copy of the mutated APC gene can cause the disease.

 

Statement 3: FAP is primarily caused by mutations in the APC gene, not KRAS. While KRAS mutations are involved in colorectal cancer progression, they are not the cause of FAP.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullet

 

The image shows a circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull, which is characteristic of a bullet wound. Beveling of the outer table indicates an exit wound, while beveling of the inner table would indicate an entry wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scissor: Incorrect. Scissor injuries typically produce irregular, non-circular wounds with sharp edges, not the circular hole seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rod: Incorrect. Injuries from a rod would usually result in linear or irregular wounds, depending on the shape and force of impact, not a circular hole.

 

Option C. Axe: Incorrect. An axe would cause a large, irregular, and typically more extensive laceration with sharp, defined edges, not a circular hole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: Imagine you are a clinician administering vaccines to a group of travelers going to a region with high Hepatitis B prevalence. One of the travelers, who has a background in biology, curiously asks which specific part of the Hepatitis B virus is actually present in the vaccine to induce an immune response. Out of the given options, which antigen is included in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) HbsAg

 

  • Hepatitis B is endemic throughout the world
  • Hepatitis B subunit vaccines consist of HBsAg (Hepatitis B virus surface antigen).
  • These vaccines are created using large molecules obtained from the immunogenic parts of pathogens through recombinant DNA technology.
  • They contrast with fully inactivated whole-cell vaccines as they exclusively contain the antigenic elements of the pathogen.
  • These elements are essential for prompting a defensive immune reaction.

 

Vaccines for Hepatitis B:

 

  • Plasma derived vaccine:
    • Is formalin inactivated sub-unit vaccine
    • Is based on HBsAg
    • Derived from carriers of Hepatitis B
    • Hepatitis B vaccine, dose schedule in adult (months) 0, 1, 6 months
  • rDNA yeast derived vaccine: Recombinant DNA vaccine (genetically engineered)

 

Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin: 

 

  • Required for immediate protection:
    • Surgeons, nurse, laboratory workers
    • Newborn infants of carrier mothers
    • Sexual contacts of acute Hepatitis B patients
    • Ideally administered within 6 hours (not later than 48 hours)

  • Dose: 0.05–0.07 mL/kg, 2 doses 30 days apart

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains HBsAg, which is essential for inducing an immune response against the virus.

choices.text: Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole
Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin
Candida albicans - Amphotericin B
Candida Krusei– Fluconazole

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida Krusei- Fluconazole

 

Candida Krusei is known to be intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, which is a widely used antifungal agent. This resistance is due to the specific genetic and biochemical characteristics of C. Kruse, which include efflux pumps that actively expel the drug and alterations in the target enzyme of fluconazole, making it less effective.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole: Aspergillus Niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole; in fact, voriconazole is one of the treatments of choice for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin: Aspergillus fumigatus is sensitive to echinocandins, including micafungin. It is not intrinsically resistant to this drug.

 

Option C. Candida albicans - Amphotericin B: Candida albicans is sensitive to amphotericin B, which is a broad-spectrum antifungal with a wide range of activity against various fungal species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

questions.text: A 65-year-old guy arrives with tense, itchy bullae over his limbs. The roof of the bullae collapsed after a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis shown in the clinical image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous pemphigoid

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

 

  • Elderly aged people are usually affected.
  • It presents as tense itchy bulla, which do not rupture easily, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & the roof of the bullae collapses after a few days forming settled bulla, autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP 230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes are seen in these patients.
  • It is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal bullae with eosinophils
  • DIF: deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction in a linear pattern.
  • It is mainly treated with Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is another autoimmune blistering disorder. However, the blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and easily ruptured as shown in the image below, as opposed to the tense bullae seen in bullous pemphigoid. Additionally, the oral mucosa is frequently involved in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) and presents with itchy papules, vesicles, and bullae. However, the distribution is typically on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees as shown in the image below, and the appearance differs from what is shown in the image in the MCQ.

 

 

Option D. Linear IgA dermatosis: This is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder. The blisters are typically in a "string of pearls" or annular arrangement as shown in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Bullous Pemphigoid is a subepidermal blistering disorder predominantly affecting the elderly, characterized by tense itchy bullae, autoantibodies against BP180 and BP230, and eosinophilic involvement."

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50, Page no. 50.4-50.37.

choices.text: Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.text: Concerning the mechanism of action of various antimicrobial drugs, which of the following statements is FALSE?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

 

Linezolid is an oxazolidinone antibiotic that actually binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, not the 30S subunit. Its mechanism of action involves the inhibition of protein synthesis by preventing the formation of a functional 70S initiation complex, which is essential for bacterial translation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: is indeed known to inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which is critical for RNA synthesis in bacteria.

 

Option C. Aztreonam: is a monobactam antibiotic that inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, thereby inhibiting peptidoglycan synthesis.

 

Option D. Daptomycin: causes depolarization of bacterial cell membranes, leading to the inhibition of all intracellular synthesis, including protein, DNA, and RNA synthesis, and ultimately cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linezolid binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, not the 30S subunit, making the statement that it binds to the 30S subunit and inhibits protein synthesis false. The other drugs mentioned have their mechanisms correctly stated.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of AMTSL? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) was described by the WHO in 2007 and involves mainly three basic steps:

 

  1. Administering a uterotonic: Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV).
  2. Controlled cord traction: This is done only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
  3. Uterine massage: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who have received uterotonics; instead, postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.

 

Key Points:

 

  • AMTSL prevents atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care. This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed.

 

WHO Guidelines:

 

  • In 2012:
    • Emphasized the main three steps.
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice.
    • Controlled cord traction only with a skilled birth attendant.
    • Delayed cord clamping recommended.
  • In 2018:
    • Additional uterotonics that can be used include:
      • Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV)
      • Misoprostol (400 or 600 mcg PO – to be used where a skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
      • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV except in hypertensive women)
      • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
    • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonics after delivery of placenta: This is a key component of AMTSL to prevent atonic PPH.

 

Option B. Controlled cord traction: This is part of the AMTSL process to help deliver the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine massage: This is included in AMTSL, specifically for assessing uterine tone post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct components of AMTSL include administering a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage. Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL; instead, delayed cord clamping is recommended.

questions.text: Identify the factor 'L' which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in given coagulation cascade? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor VII

 

The factor marked as 'L' is factor VII, which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX.

 

 

Thrombin also activates factor XIlI, which is the fibrin stabilizing factor to factor XIlla. This factor XIlla forms covalent cross-links and thereby stabilizes the fibrin clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII: Involved in the initiation of the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Works as a cofactor for Factor IXa in the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option D. VWF (Von Willebrand Factor): Involved in platelet adhesion and stabilization of Factor VIII but is not involved in the activation of the coagulation cascade by tissue factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor VII is the key clotting factor that combines with tissue factor to activate Factor IX and Factor X, playing a crucial role in the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Albert's stain- I
  2. Acid alcohol
  3. Gram's iodine
  4. Safranin
  5. Methylene blue
  6. Crystal violet
  7. Carbol fuschin
  8. Acetone
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

 

The image shows Gram's stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae are gram +ve rod shaped bacteria, Club shaped, non-capsulated, non sporing, non-motile,. Also known as Kleb’s-Loeffler Bacillus.

 

The Gram staining process includes four basic steps, including:

 

  1. Applying a primary stain (crystal violet). Option 6
  2. Adding a mordant (Gram’s iodine). Option 3
  3. Rapid decolorization with ethanol, acetone or a mixture of both. Option 8
  4. Counterstaining with safranin. Option 4

 

On microscopy –

 

  • Chinese letter arrangement, V or L shaped
  • Forms granules (metachromatic granules) which are the store house of energy.
  • Alberts’s stain, Loeffler’s methylene blue stain and Ponder’s stain shows metachromatic granules formed in the polar regions. Appears green in Alberts’s stain along with bluish black metachromatic granules at the poles.
    • Albert's I solution - Toluidine blue, Malachite green.
    • Albert's II solution - iodine and potassium iodide.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

 

Explanation:

 

Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:

 

  • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.

 

Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Histological examination of a cervical lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The histological image shows a lot of pink areas, indicative of necrosis, and an inflammatory infiltrate. These features are suggestive of caseous necrosis, surrounded by a ring of lymphocytes, which is characteristic of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis often affects the cervical lymph nodes, leading to their enlargement and caseous necrosis, commonly referred to as "matting" of the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect. Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas and commonly affects the lungs and hilar lymph nodes, not typically the cervical lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Langerhans cell histiocytosis: Incorrect. This condition would show Langerhans cells (which have a characteristic appearance) and is not associated with the caseous necrosis seen in the image.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma: Incorrect. Hodgkin lymphoma presents with Reed Sternberg cells and does not show caseous necrosis. Although Hodgkin lymphoma can cause cervical lymph node enlargement, it does not fit the granulomatous inflammation pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of caseous necrosis and a ring of lymphocytes in the histological examination of cervical lymph nodes strongly suggests tuberculosis as the diagnosis.

 

Histological Hallmarks of TB in Lymph Nodes:

 

  • Caseating granulomas (granulomas with central necrosis)
  • Surrounding epithelioid histiocytes, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes
  • Necrosis is a key differentiator from sarcoidosis (which has non-caseating granulomas)

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night blindness is a late feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a group of hereditary disorders that cause progressive degeneration of the retina, specifically affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones).

 

Night blindness is a late feature: This is incorrect. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is an early feature of RP. Patients often present with difficulties in dark adaptation and night vision long before significant peripheral vision loss occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave: Electroretinography (ERG) in RP patients shows decreased amplitude of both the a wave (originating from rods and cones) and the b wave (originating from bipolar cells).

 

Option B. Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy: RP typically starts with rod dysfunction, which later involves the cones.

 

Option C. Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision: RP usually presents with mid-peripheral vision loss, which progresses to peripheral vision loss and eventually central vision loss, leading to tunnel vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: 3-point bony relationship is maintained in which fracture?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

THREE POINT BONY LANDMARKS IN ELBOW

 

  • Tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and olecranon
  • Form isosceles triangle with elbow in 90° flexion
  • Lie transversely in straight line in elbow extension

 

 

  • Three-point bony relationship is not disturbed in fracture supracondylar humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.
  • With disturbed (increased) intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture lateral epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture medial epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture intercondylar humerus.
  • With maintained intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture olecranon (i.e. upper end ulna)
    • Elbow dislocation (classical example)
  • Waeak posterior capsule may disrupt three-point bony relation by promoting subluxation or dislocations of elbow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation. In elbow dislocation, the intercondylar distance is maintained but the three-point bony relationship is disturbed.

 

Option C. Intercondylar humerus fracture. In this fracture, the intercondylar distance is disturbed i.e., increased, so is the three-point bony relationship.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.

questions.text: Which JAK inhibitor drug is recommended for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in a patient who is not responding well to TNF-alpha blockers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tofacitinib

 

Tofacitinib is a JAK (Janus Kinase) inhibitor that is specifically approved for treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in patients who have failed or are not responding to TNF-alpha blockers. It represents a different mechanism of action compared to TNF-alpha inhibitors, making it a suitable alternative for patients who have failed anti-TNF therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ustekinumab: Incorrect. While it can be used in inflammatory bowel disease, it is a combined anti-IL-12 and IL-23 blocker, not a JAK inhibitor.

 

Option B. Etanercept: Incorrect. This is an anti-TNF drug, and the question specifically asks about patients who are not responding to TNF-alpha blockers.

 

Option C. Vedolizumab: Incorrect. This is an α4β7 integrin blocker used in IBD, but not a JAK inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tofacitinib is the JAK inhibitor approved for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in patients who have failed TNF-alpha blockers. Other JAK inhibitors used in rheumatological diseases include baricitinib and upadacitinib.

questions.text: All of the following Decreases GFR except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased Bowman Oncotic Pressure

 

The GFR is calculated using the formula: GFR = Kf × Net Filtration Pressure (NFP).

 

Net Filtration Pressure is determined by the balance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures in the glomerular and Bowman's capsule. 

 

The Net Filtration Pressure (NFP) is calculated using the formula: NFP = (HPG - OPG) - (HPB - OPB) Where:

 

  • HPG = Hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries (pushing force, ~60 mmHg)
  • OPG = Oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries (pulling force, ~32 mmHg)
  • HPB = Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule (opposing force, ~18 mmHg)
  • OPB = Oncotic pressure in Bowman's capsule (normally negligible, ~0 mmHg)

 

Normally, NFP = (60-32) - (18-0) = 10 mmHg

 

When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space. This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased glomerular coefficient Kf: Incorrect because a decrease in Kf directly reduces GFR according to the formula GFR = Kf × NFP. The glomerular coefficient represents the permeability of the filtration membrane and its surface area.

 

Option B. Increase glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect because glomerular oncotic pressure is a pulling force that opposes filtration. When oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries increases, it holds water within the capillaries, reducing the amount of filtrate formed, thereby decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Reduced Glomerular Hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect because glomerular hydrostatic pressure is the primary driving force for filtration. A reduction in this pressure means less force is available to push water and solutes across the filtration membrane, resulting in decreased GFR.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space. This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.

questions.text:
Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Pulmonary area

2.Erb’s area

3.Mitral area
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 → 2 → 3

 

The heart sounds are heard in the following order from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall:

 

Pulmonary area: 2nd intercostal space near the sternum →Erb’s area (2nd aortic area): 3rd intercostal space near the sternum → Mitral area: 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line (away from sternum).


Educational Objective:

 

The correct order from superior to inferior for heart sounds on the left side chest wall is pulmonary area, Erb’s area, and mitral area.

choices.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

 

The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible bladder injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Trauma to lower abdomen with blood at urethral meatus implies urethral rupture. The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible urethral injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and then do a suprapubic cystostomy.

 

After bladder fills up with urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is done in immediate management of urethral rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and send her home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a possible urethral injury.

 

Option B. Immediate insertion of Foley catheter: This option involves the insertion of a small tube through the urethra and into the bladder to drain urine. This is contraindicated in suspected urethral rupture, as it may create false passage.

 

Option C. Suprapubic aspiration of urine: This option involves inserting a needle through the skin and into the bladder to aspirate urine. This option may be preferred in cases where the urethra is injured or obstructed, making the insertion of a Foley catheter difficult. For this to be done, the bladder should be distended.

choices.text: Epithelial cell tumor
Germ cell tumor
Sex cord stromal tumor
Granulosa cell tumor

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell tumor

 

Explanation:


Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified under epithelial cell tumors. Epithelial ovarian tumors originate from the cells that line the surface of the ovary. Clear cell carcinoma is a subtype of epithelial ovarian tumors.

 

Classification of ovarian tumors:

 

  1. Epithelial Cell Tumor
    • Serous
    • Mucinous
    • Brenner
    • Clear cell
    • Endometrioid
    • Clear cell carcinoma falls under this category.
  2. Germ Cell Tumor
    • Dysgerminoma
    • Yolk sac tumor
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma
    • Embryonal
    • Clear cell carcinoma is not classified here.
  3. Sex Cord Stromal Tumor
    • Granulosa cell tumor
    • Thecoma
    • Fibroma
    • Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor
    • Clear cell carcinoma is not included in this category.

 

Educational Objective:


Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified as an epithelial cell tumor.

 

Ref: Page no 291, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Imagine being part of a team aiming to identify the link between a novel nutritional supplement and its potential effects on muscle growth. You're tasked with deciding the most appropriate study design to establish a cause-and-effect relationship. Among the given options, which study design would be the most effective for demonstrating a connection between cause and effect? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

  • Cohort study is the most effective study design for showcasing the connection between a cause and an effect. A cohort study is a type of analytical (observational) study used for ‘hypothesis testing’. It is known by several synonyms:
    • Prospective study
    • Forward looking study
    • Cause to effect study
    • Exposure to outcome study
    • Risk factor to disease study
    • Incidence study
    • Follow up study

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-control study: Case Control Study cannot provide with incidences, so Relative Risk cannot be calculated; In a Case Control Study, we calculate ‘an estimate of Relative Risk’, known as ‘Odds Ratio’ (CROSS PRODUCT RATIO).

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: A cross-sectional study is based on the single examination of a cross-section of a population ‘at one point of time’, results of sample are then projected to whole population. It cannot establish causality as ‘does not establish time sequence’.

 

Option D. Clinical trials: Clinical trials evaluates new studies, drugs and treatment effects on human population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cohort studies are ideal for establishing cause-and-effect relationships by following exposures over time and observing outcomes.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are false about IL-12 except? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases production of interferon- γ
  2. Inhibits T cells
  3. Inhibits B cells
  4. Produced by macrophages
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is a cytokine produced primarily by antigen-presenting cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells. It plays a critical role in the immune response by promoting the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells, which are essential for cell-mediated immunity.

 

1. Increases production of interferon-γ (IFN-γ): IL-12 stimulates T cells and natural killer (NK) cells to produce IFN-γ, a cytokine crucial for the immune response against intracellular pathogens.

 

4. Produced by macrophages: IL-12 is indeed produced by macrophages, along with other antigen-presenting cells, in response to pathogens.

 

Other options:

 

2. Inhibits T cells: This is incorrect. IL-12 actually activates T cells, particularly promoting the differentiation into Th1 cells, rather than inhibiting them.

 

3. Inhibits B cells: This is also incorrect. IL-12 does not inhibit B cells; instead, it indirectly influences B cell function by promoting a Th1 response, which supports cellular immunity over humoral (B cell) immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is produced by macrophages and increases the production of interferon- γ (IFN- γ).
